title: Dad who suffered painful three-day erection now has pump-up groin
text:
James Mudd, 38, had a three-day erection and had to undergo surgery (Picture: Joe Newman/ Triangle News)

A father-of-four who suffered a painful three-day erection now has an ‘inflatable’ penis after undergoing surgery.

James Mudd, 38, had previously had an operation to drain the blood from his penis after struggling with agonisingly long erections which could last up until six hours at a time.

But in November 2017, the day before his birthday, his penis refused to go down and he was forced to call the NHS helpline for advice.

They told him to run a freezing cold bath, run up and down the stairs, and take painkillers to thin his blood – but nothing worked.

After 56 hours, James, of Canning Town, east London, could no longer walk and had to call an ambulance to rush him to University College Hospital.

Doctors have now put in a pump he can use (Picture: Triangle News)

He said: ‘I was angry, I was upset, I was scared. I cannot explain the pain of it, it was like it was going to explode.’

James had corrective surgery and screws put into his neck after coming off his motorbike just after Christmas in 2015.

The crash caused him to suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder, and medics believe his prescribed anti-depressants are what caused issues with his penis.

After arriving at hospital, James underwent seven-and-a-half hours of surgery, but doctors told him he would need another operation to prevent it from happening again.

He said: ‘I had so many questions. Can I still sleep with women? Can I still have kids? Can I still go to the toilet? God blessed me quite well, what is going to happen?’

In April 2018, doctors put in a saline sack inside his genitals and a pump to inflate his groin if he wants to have an erection.

James was then forced to spend six weeks unable to touch his penis before finding out if it had been successful.

The father-of-four will be able to have more children (Picture: Triangle News)

He was too embarrassed to tell his friends or family, and his long-term girlfriend had broken up with him the week before the operation, causing him to describe it as a ‘really stressful time’.

The council worker said: ‘I was walking like John Wayne. I was terrified it wasn’t going to be alright. but it’s healed and looks completely natural.’

Medics had told him he ‘didn’t know how lucky’ he was that they could save his penis, as it was a ‘unique case’.

Describing his penis as a ‘blessing in disguise’, he said: ‘It is absolutely brilliant. It’s up to you when you want to stop.’

He added: ‘I’m over the moon with it. It has humbled me a lot.’

description: James Mudd, 38, struggled with agonising long erections that once lasted three days and saw him undergo emergency surgery.
